results.title: Le Desordre a Vingt Ans = Disorder Is Twenty Years Old
results.brief_description:
In this documentary, Jacques Baratier compares life in the St Germain des Pres area of Paris in the the post WWII years and 20 years later in the Sixties (pre May 68). Rare documents and seldom seen footage of personalities, “overexposed films shot in obscure places” such as ‘Le Tabou’ recreate the ambiance of the great existentialist era. The interviewees recall the social changes that led to the movement. They include: Boris Vian, Alain Vian, Roger Blin, Juliette Greco, Raymond Queneau, Jean Cau, Simone de Beauvoir, Jean-Paul Sartre, Sophie Desmarets, Jean Cocteau, Roger Pierre, Arthur Adamov, Cesar, Anne-Marie Cazalis, Michel de Re, Roger Vadim, Annabel, Gabriel Pomerand, Sydney Bechet, Claude Luter etc… This film is followed by ‘Voila l’ordre’.

Credits: Director, Jacques Baratier.

results.title: Benito Cereno
results.brief_description:
In 1799, the Santo Domingo is sailing to Peru, when a slave mutiny erupts on board. Only seven crew members survive, including the Captain, Benito Cereno. The leader of the mutiny, Atimbo, wants to sail back to Africa. When the ship encounters troubles, an American vessel comes to the rescue. Cereno explains that his crew has taken ill with scurvy, including the human cargo imported from Africa. The slaves are down to only a few healthy men and Cereno is awaiting the right

Credits: Director, Serge Roullet ; writer, Serge Roullet ; photography, Ricardo Arronovitch.
Cast: Ruy Guerra, Georges Selmark, Temour Diop, Jacques Mercier, John Turner, Serge Roullet, Philippe Noury.

results.title: Le Vieil Homme et L' Enfant = the Old Man and the Boy
results.brief_description:
During the nazi occupation of Paris, an irrepressible eight-year old jewish boy, Claude, is sent to stay with an elderly couple in the country. Since Pepe, the old man, is a rabid anti-semite, the boy is instructed to conceal his origins. Once there, Claude and Pepe forge a close relationship - beautifully realized in the playing - in which the boy is amused by the old man’s bigoted outburst and delights in provoking him, while Pepe comes to dote on the child. Berri’s film is a reconstruction of his own childhood experience and he describes it as a ‘love affair between a Jew and an anti-Semite’. Awards: Berlin Film Festival (1967): Best Actor for Michel Simon.

Credits: Director, Claude Berri ; writers, Gerard Brach, Claude Berri ; photography, Jean Penzer ; music, Georges Delerue.
Cast: Michel Simon, Alain Cohen, Charles Denner, Luce Fabiole, Roger Carel, Paul Preboist, Zorica Lozice.

results.title: The Last seduction
results.creator_credit: John Dahl, Jonathan Shestack and ITC Entertainment Group
results.brief_description: An updated film noir centering around Bridget Gregory, a beautiful, intelligent and ambitious femme fatal. After convincing her doctor husband to pull off a $700,000 cocaine deal, Bridget takes of with the money and hides out in a small town, where she meets Mike. She is tracked down by a private investigator hired by her husband. As the two start to close in on Bridget, she involves Mike in an elaborate scheme to keep the money and get rid of her husband. Cast includes: Linda Fiorentino, Peter Berg, Bill Pullman, J.T. Walsh and Bill Nunn. (Awards: New York)

results.title: Journal D'une Femme de Chambre = Diary of a Chambermaid (Cinemascope Print)
results.creator_credit: Luis Bunuel, Michel Safra and Serge Silberman
results.brief_description:
Celestine takes up a position as chambermaid in a middle-class family and becomes the catalyst that reveals their sexual, religious and social repressions. The film, foot fetishism and all, is pure Bunuel, a sharp social satire in which the sexy, cruel and cool Jeanne Moreau is wonderful. Jean Renoir directed a version of ‘Le journal d’une femme de chambre’ in 1934.

Credits: Producers, Serge Silberman, Michel Safra; director, Luis Bunuel ; writers, Luis Bunuel, Jean-Claude Carriere ; photography, Roger Fellous ; art direction, Georges Wakhevitch.
Cast: Jeanne Moreau, Michel Piccoli, Francoise Lugagne, Georges Geret, Jean Geret, Daniel Ivernel, Gilberte Geniat, Muni, Dominique Sauvage, Jean-Claude Carriere, Jean Ozenne, Andree Tainsy.

results.title: Nathalie Granger
results.brief_description:
With little or no embellishment, film-maker Marguerite Duras offers a simple, often wordless chronicle of a woman’s day. She and her friend are seen doing yard work, talking about their families and receiving the occasional visitor. The brightest spot in the day is when a washing machine salesman comes to call.

Cast: Jeanne Moreau, Lucia Bose, Gerard Depardieu, Valerie Mascolo, Dionys Mascolo, Luce Garcia-Ville.

results.title: Kundun
results.creator_credit: Martin Scorsese, Barbara de Fina, Cappa Productions, Refuge Productions and Touchstone Pictures
results.brief_description: Scorsese’s drama detailing the Dalai Lama’s life story was in development for seven years, with the Dalai Lama having input into the 14 screenplay drafts. With four actors portraying the Dalai Lama at different ages, the film begins in 1933 with the death of the 13th Dalai Lama. Born in a remote area, the new Dalai Lama (seen at ages two and five in early sequences) is observed by monks who determine that he is the 14th reincarnation of the Buddha of Compassion. In 1944 he uses newsreels and Western magazines to study WWII events, and as the war ends, he is forced to deal with Chinese Communist aggression. Mao’s military stranglehold on Tibet eventually forces the Dalai Lama to flee to Dharmsala, India. Commenting on the “anti-spiritual…Marxist government of the Chinese Communists,” Scorsese remarked, “What interests me is how a man of non-violence deals with these people - that’s ultimately the story.” With a $28 million budget, he re-created Tibet’s tragedy by filming in south-central Morocco with a cast of nonprofessional Tibetan actors. Second unit work took place at locations in Idaho and British Columbia. Cast includes Tenzin Thuthob Tsarong, Gyurme Ththong, Tencho Gyalpo, Tsewang Migyur Khangsar and Sonam Phunstok.

results.title: Comedian harmonists
results.creator_credit: Joseph Vilsmaier, Bavaria Film, Iduna, Perathon and Senator
results.brief_description: A dramatised account of the legendary German singing group ‘Comedian Harmonists’. Consisting of five singers and a pianist this close harmony group combined smooth melodies and comedy routines, performing jazz songs and German favorites in their own idiosyncratic style. They sang in several languages and starred in more than a dozen films. Vilsmaier tells the story of the groups rise to fame, their international success in the late twenties and early thirties, and their demise in 1934 when the Nazis branded their music as ‘degraded’ and prohibited it- three of the six musicians were Jewish. Essentially an affectionate tribute to the group, the film adopts the style of the traditional musical biopic. As with his earlier films ‘Herbstmilch’, ‘Rama Dama’ and ‘Stalingrad’, in this film Vilsmaier once again focuses on Germany in the 1930’s effectively portraying the treatment of Jewish artists during the National Socialism-Era. Cast includes Ben Becker, Heino Ferch, Ulrich Noethen, Heinrich Schafmeister, Kai Wiesinger, Katja Riemann, Meret Becker and Otto Sander. In German with English subtitles.

results.title: L'horloger de Saint Paul = the Clockmaker of Saint Paul
results.brief_description:
For his first feature film, Bertrand Tavernier chose to transport the Simenon characters to his native town of Lyons. Michel Descombes works as a clockmaker in the St-Paul area of Lyons. One evening he finds the Police at his door asking about his son, Bernard. Bernard is suspected of shooting a security guard at a factory and has run away with his girlfriend. As the Police enquiry progresses, Michel realises he knows very little about his son and can hardly assist Commissioner Guiboud. The choice of Aurenche and Bost as screenwriters can be regarded as an anti ‘Nouvelle Vague’ statement from Tavernier. Both writers were strongly associated with film-makers such as Claude Autant-Lara and a more traditional style of cinema. Awards: Prix Louis Delluc 1973 ; Berlin Film Festival 1974 - Special Jury Prize.

Credits: Producer, Raymond Danon ; director, Bertrand Tavernier ; writers, Jean Aurenche, Pierre Bost, Bertrand Tavernier ; photography, Pierre-William Glenn ; music, Philippe Sarde.
Cast: Philippe Noiret, Jean Rochefort, Jacques Denis, Clotilde Joanno, Sylvain Rougerie, Christine Pascal, Monique Chaumette, William Sabatier.

results.title: Beat the devil (Special edition)
results.creator_credit: John Huston, Jack Clayton, Romulus Films and Santana
results.brief_description: The story of a motley group of swindlers travelling on an Africa-bound tramp steamer. The plot unfolds to reveal a web of double crossing and deception as each attempts to get their hands on a fortune in uranium deposits. Starring Gina Lollobrigida and Humphrey Bogart. Written by Truman Capote and John Huston from a novel by James Helvick. This version includes an introduction by Tony Curtis and a bonus clip of the original theatrical trailer for Humphrey Bogart’s ‘The Big sleep’.
